jparsec.observer

Class ObserverElement

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.observer.ObserverElement
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class ObserverElement
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    An adequate class for storing the position of an observer as a previous step to calculate ephemerides.

    This class is suitable for storing data from the city and observatory classes. It contains some methods to parse a CityElement or an ObservatoryElement object. It is possible to store atmospheric conditions like pressure and temperature, values that will be used when obtaining the apparent elevation of an object.

    A special feature is to set the location of the observer to a given point located in another planet or within the Solar System, using the class ExtraterrestrialObserverElement.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)
    See Also:
    CityElement, ObservatoryElement, Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • ObserverElement

        public ObserverElement()
        Constructs an empty observer. All values to 0.0 or empty strings.

      • ObserverElement

        public ObserverElement(java.lang.String loc_name,
               double loc_lon,
               double loc_lat,
               int loc_alt,
               double tz)
        Constructs a observer by giving the values of the fields. Pressure and temperature are set to default values.
        Parameters:
        loc_name - Name of the city/observatory, or otherwise the user location.
        loc_lon - Longitude in radians. West negative.
        loc_lat - Latitude in radians.
        loc_alt - Altitude in meters.
        tz - Time zone in hours.

      • ObserverElement

        public ObserverElement(java.lang.String loc_name,
               double loc_lon,
               double loc_lat,
               int loc_alt,
               double tz,
               ObserverElement.DST_RULE dst)
        Constructs a observer by giving the values of all the main fields. Pressure and temperature are set to default values.
        Parameters:
        loc_name - Name of the city/observatory, or otherwise the user location.
        loc_lon - Longitude in radians. West negative.
        loc_lat - Latitude in radians.
        loc_alt - Altitude in meters.
        tz - Time zone in hours.
        dst - DST rule.

      • ObserverElement

        public ObserverElement(java.lang.String loc_name,
               double loc_lon,
               double loc_lat,
               int loc_alt,
               double tz,
               ObserverElement.DST_RULE dst,
               int pres,
               int temp,
               int humi,
               ReferenceEllipsoid.ELLIPSOID ellipsoid,
               double[] target)
        Constructs a observer by giving the values of the fields.
        Parameters:
        loc_name - Name of the city/observatory, or otherwise the user location.
        loc_lon - Longitude in radians. West negative.
        loc_lat - Latitude in radians.
        loc_alt - Altitude in meters.
        tz - Time zone in hours.
        dst - The DST rule.
        pres - Pressure in milibars.
        temp - Temperature in Celsius.
        humi - Humidity as a percentage, from 0 to 100.
        ellipsoid - The ellipsoid for the mother body.
        target - The barycentric equatorial vector of the observer (position and velocity) in J2000 equinox (mean coordinates) for non-Earth centered ephemerides.

      • ObserverElement

        public ObserverElement(java.lang.String ip)
                throws JPARSECException
        Creates an Observer object by using geolocalization to automatically find the position of the user, using ipinfodb.com.
        Parameters:
        ip - The IP to be located, or null (or empty string) to use the current computer IP.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs during the query.

        The ellipsoid.

      • geodeticToGeocentric

        public static LocationElement geodeticToGeocentric(ReferenceEllipsoid.ELLIPSOID ellipsoid,
                                   double longitude,
                                   double latitude,
                                   int height)
        Transform from geodetic to geocentric coordinates. The geocentric distance is set to Earth equatorial radii. For reference see Astronomical Almanac, page K5.
        Parameters:
        ellipsoid - The reference ellipsoid for input geodetic location.
        longitude - The longitude.
        latitude - The latitude.
        height - Height above sea level.
        Returns:
        The location from the geocenter, distance in units of Earth's equatorial radius.

      • geocentricToGeodetic

        public static LocationElement geocentricToGeodetic(ReferenceEllipsoid.ELLIPSOID ellipsoid,
                                   double geoLon,
                                   double geoLat,
                                   double geoRad)
        Transform from geocentric/planetocentric coordinates to geodetic. The geodetic distance is set as a height above mean elipsoid height. The method is an analitical inversion of the geodetic to geocentric transformation, that produces an slightly error in latitude in the milliarcsecond level.
        Parameters:
        ellipsoid - The reference ellipsoid.
        geoLon - Geocentric longitude.
        geoLat - Geocentric latitude.
        geoRad - Geocentric distance in units of Earth's equatorial radius.
        Returns:
        Geodetic location as longitude, latitude, and elevation above sea level in m.

      • getDistance

        public static double getDistance(ObserverElement obs1,
                 ObserverElement obs2)
        Returns the distance between two observers, supposing they are on Earth surface and at sea level. From Astronomical Algorithms, chapter 10. Accuracy of about 50 m.
        Parameters:
        obs1 - First observer.
        obs2 - Second observer. The coordinates are supposed to be referred to the same ellipsoid as the first observer.
        Returns:
        Distance in km.

      • forceObserverOnEarth

        public void forceObserverOnEarth()
        Forces the observer to be on Earth by setting the body to Earth and the ellipsoid to the latest Earth's ellipsoid.

      • parseCity

        public static ObserverElement parseCity(CityElement city)
                                 throws JPARSECException
        Gets the ObserverElement of certain CityElement.
        Parameters:
        city - The city to parse.
        Returns:
        The corresponding observer.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the method fails.

      • parseObservatory

        public static ObserverElement parseObservatory(ObservatoryElement observatory)
                                        throws JPARSECException
        Gets the observer of certain observatory. Note 0.0 is the output for the time zone offset due to a lack of information. DST rule is set to the country where the observatory lies, if it is found.
        Parameters:
        observatory - The observatory to parse.
        Returns:
        The corresponding observer.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the method fails.

      • parseExtraterrestrialObserver

        public static ObserverElement parseExtraterrestrialObserver(ExtraterrestrialObserverElement et)
                                                     throws JPARSECException
        Gets the observer for certain extraterrestrial object. Time zone and elevation above reference level is set to 0, and dst rule to NONE. Any calculation with this kind of observer should never be done in local time, since local time is for an observer on Earth. Anyway, just take into account that for an observer in other body local time = UTC.
        Parameters:
        et - The extraterrestrial object.
        Returns:
        The corresponding observer.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the method fails.

      • obtainElevation

        public void obtainElevation(boolean useBumpMap)
        Sets the elevation approximately by using an Earth bump map. The method will adjust the height field or will do nothing if there is a problem accessing the map or an error during calculations.
        Parameters:
        useBumpMap - True to use a bump map, false to find closest city. In the latter case the location name will be also updated in case it is empty or null, and daylight saving time rule and time zone will also be updated.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a String representation of this object.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • getGeodeticLocation

        public LocationElement getGeodeticLocation()
        Returns the observer's position as a LocationElement object.
        Returns:
        The position. Radius is set as height above sea level in m.

      • getGeocentricLocation

        public LocationElement getGeocentricLocation()
                                      throws JPARSECException
        Returns the observer's geocentric position as a LocationElement object.
        Returns:
        The position. Radius is set as geocentric distance in units of Earth's equatorial radii.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the observer is not on a Solar System body.

      • correctObserverForPolarMotion

        public void correctObserverForPolarMotion(TimeElement time,
                                 EphemerisElement eph)
                                   throws JPARSECException
        Corrects geodetic coordinates by polar motion. This correction amounts to about 10m, and it is not required most of the times (only for precise apparent positions). This correction, however, can improve ephemerides for Moon by about 2 mas, and those for artificial satellites by several arcseconds. JPARSEC never calls this method.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object.
        eph - Ephemeris object.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • topocentricObserverICRF

        public double[] topocentricObserverICRF(TimeElement time,
                               EphemerisElement eph)
                                 throws JPARSECException
        Return geocentric rectangular coordinates of the observer in the ICRF system, for J2000 mean equinox and equator (GCRS coordinates). In case the ephemerides properties are set to geocentric, this method returns 0 for all components.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object.
        eph - Ephemeris object.
        Returns:
        (x, y, z, vx, vy, vz) of observer in AU and AU/d. Zero values for geocentric ephemerides.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the method fails, for example because of an invalid date or reference ellipsoid.

      • heliocentricPositionOfObserver

        public double[] heliocentricPositionOfObserver(double JD_TDB,
                                      EphemerisElement eph)
                                        throws JPARSECException
        Return heliocentric equatorial rectangular coordinates of the observer's mother body in case the observer is not located on Earth.
        Parameters:
        JD_TDB - Julian day in TDB.
        eph - Ephemeris object.
        Returns:
        (x, y, z, vx, vy, vz) of observer in AU and AU/d, for J2000 equinox and equator.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getMotherBodyMeanRotationRate

        public double getMotherBodyMeanRotationRate(EphemerisElement eph)
                                     throws JPARSECException
        Returns the mean rotation rate of a given body.
        Parameters:
        eph - Ephemeris properties containing body and ephemeris method.
        Returns:
        The rotation rate in radians/second. 0 is returned for geocentric ephemerides.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        For unit testing only
        Parameters:
        args - Not used.
